reviewText:
If you're looking for some long story about how Sam, Tycho, the Heavy and Strong Bad all ended up playing poker ... well, there's not much of one. It's just the four of them hanging out and playing at The Inventory, an underground club that supposedly has its roots in Prohibiton, but offers nothing more than a setting. And that's fine, because really, this game doesn't have a need for a story.

Visually, Poker Night's a good looking game. The Heavy, Strong Bad and Max all use models from Valve and Telltale's games, respectively, and their animations are very smooth. Tycho's model, on the other hand, is brand-new, and oddly enough, he's the one who looks a little out of place from time to time. There's also a few graphical glitches if you move the game along too fast: in one instance, I couldn't see my cards for an entire hand because they never actually loaded. I'd folded too quickly and skipped to the end of the hand before the game could make the change, it seems.

Another cool little feature is that in the background, the characters will appear as you knock them out of the game. They don't do a whole lot, but it's kind of cool to see Strong Bad playing the arcade machine, or the Heavy at the bar after a bitter defeat at the table.

Where Poker Night excels, though, is in the chatter at the table between the Heavy, Tycho, Strong Bad and Max. The scritping and the actual voice acting itself is spot-on, a testament to the abilities of whoever's responsible at Telltale for writing this game's dialogue. Tycho's voice is a bit jarring at first, but you get used to it the more you play, until it seems natural.

What's also great is that each character's quirks are also included in their dialogue: for example, there are Heavy's funny" stories about summer camp that are actually quite morbid

reviewText:
Warning: if you're here to buy the game just for the TF2 items but you have no idea how to play Texas-Hold-Em, you're not going to have any fun with this.

With that aside, PNATI is relatively a fun, (sometimes unfair) take on Texas Hold Em. You play cards against the Heavy from TF2, Tycho from Penny Arcade, Max from the Sam & Max series and Strong Bad from the online series Homestar Runner. The dialogue and conversations that the characters have is quite interesting and funny, and the actual gameplay itself stays true to the original rules of Texas-Hold-Em.

The only problem I've seen so far is that the A.I. is a crapshoot and will sometimes unfairly beat you even when you think you have the best hand possible. With that said, with a basic understanding of how the A.I. works and of course, the rules of Texas Hold Em, the game becomes easy, perhaps a little TOO easy. The weapons and items themselves are quite unique-looking, despite only being reskins of the stock items.

Overall, I'd say it's alright at the most, but there's not a lot of replay value to be had, and if you're just getting into it, I reccommend you do your research beforehand to see how to play it.

Words cannot express how much hype I had when I first saw the trailer for this. All of the characters (except for Tycho, who I was honestly unfamiliar with at the time) together was just something so hard for me to process. I also somehow didn't expect it to actually be a poker game before release, so I had to learn it.

Thankfully this game is pretty easy to handle once you get the feel for it. I think most sales honestly came from TF2, where you get some unlocks from this game. But I honestly find myself revisiting this every now and then just to hear all the characters talk to each other. Especially Strong Bad and Heavy, like TF2 and Homestar Runner together was a huge thing for me. Almost disappointing all classes couldn't wear the Dangeresque shades, but I still wore them proudly.

Actually diving into it. Of course all the characters are amazing, granted you recognize them all. And it provides for some  amazing talk between them all (and you will eventually hear all the lines if you play it enough). You get rewarded (as said above) not only for TF2, but you can also unlock different tabletops and stuff. Granted you're good enough at poker unlike me. In the end, it's really just that. A well planned out and put together poker game with 4 very memorable characters all from different series.

Unfortunately Poker Night 2 was an unfair mess that was truly annoying (at least in my opinion) and had sorta boring unlocks for TF2.

Forgetting about that. If you wanna see Homestar Runner, Sam & Max, Penny Arcade, and the TF2 universe combined just to play a simple game of poker, this is definitely worth the $5.

reviewText:
Let’s face it; most people buy this game purely for the items you can earn for yourself on team fortress 2.
If that really is the only reason why you are on the store page, then there are ways of getting those items relatively quickly.
It took me around 3 hours to get all 4 of the items, and I personally don’t think that is too shabby, the AI in this game is pretty bad… and easy to manipulate, or at least that is what I thought. All I did was start up a game, if one of them puts their item up, great, carry on, if not… I restarted the game until one of them did. And from there, went all-in every hand in a complete gamble, because sometimes they call and you knock them out and get their item right there. You can do it any way you like, but if you are lazy like me and can’t be bothered, it’s a fairly easy way to “earn” those items. And hey hoe it only left me around $600,000 in debt.
On the other hand, if you are looking at this game, not for the items, but for actual gameplay… there isn’t really much you can say,
as mentioned before the AI in this game is terrible, it is repetitive and you can start to sus out patterns that the characters have. Their dialog you can tell is trying to be laid back, friendly chum-to-chum talk with one another, and in all fairness some of it is amusing… the first 5 times. The dialog is so frequent and repetitive that after a little while, I really started to get annoyed with what they were saying. I don’t play many poker type games with the gambling and whatnot, but the feel from the game isn’t what I would imagine a real person interested in poker would be looking for. It doesn’t feel like real poker… or a real game… it seems dumbed down.
Now that I have gotten all the items, I really don’t think I will ever be playing this game again.

reviewText: From the creaters of the Sam and Max games, here comes Poker Night at the Inventory. The games setting is in a secret hideout known as The Inventory, where people from various medias hang out and play some poker games. You play Texas Hold Em and compete against Max from Sam and Max, Strong Bad from the Homestar Runner videos, Heavy from Team Fortress 2 and Tycho from Penny Arcades and find out who will go big or go home. There's not too much to say about this game, it's just Texas Hold Em. Occasionaly someone will toss in a buy in if they are short on cash, being able to win the buy in will unlock an exclusive item in TF2 like Strong Bad's Dangeresque Too? Glasses and others. The dialouge between the players is always fun to watch after a hand. The conversations with Heavy and Tycho are funny as Heavy thinks Tycho is part of BLU Team as well as the ones with Strong Bad and Heavy and how Heavy finds him to be a smaller version of himself, or Tiny Heavy as he likes to call him. The one thing this game needs is Online play, it would be cool having more players in on the event or have them play as the multi-media characters. So in conclusion, Poker Night at the Inventory is a fun poker game where you don't have to waste realy money in order to play through the game. And since the game usually sells at $5.00 and features exclusive content in TF2, ya can't go wrong there.

reviewText:
Presenation
Poker Night at the Inventory isn't the most authentic and packed poker experience out there, mostly because it was never meant to be, but it is among the most enjoyable virtual poker experiences while it lasts. You will be simply known as the Player, a newcomer to the secret poker club known as the Inventory, taking part in five players tournaments against four memorable characters from different franchises, not only in the video games industry, but comics and video series as well. You will play against Max from Telltale's own Sam & Max franchise, Strong Bad from Homestar Runner, Tycho from Penny Arcade, and the Heavy from Team Fortress 2, characters that have absolutely nothing common, yet still manage to lighten up the mood at the poker table. Poker Night's magic comes from the conversation between those characters, which consists mostly of jokes and references, and while some were meant to be little easter eggs for fans of a particular franchise, most jokes appeal to a generic audience, making them hilarious even if you're not that familiar with the characters. A short introduction to each of your adversaries would've been welcome to familiarize the player with their background, but instead the game chooses to introduce them to you as you play via dialogue, which feels authentic to a poker experience, but ultimately falls short on how much information you will actually get. Nonetheless, the jokes are what make Poker Night at the Inventory a fun experience more than anything else, but unfortunately the amount of dialogue doesn't go on forever, and one or two hours in, the game will run out of new dialogue and start repeating itself over and over again.
Rating: 6.5

Gameplay
There's no surprise or twist in here, what you actually play is poker, Texas Hold'em to be more specific, and that is another big reason why this game will become boring within a few hours; Texas Hold'em is the only thing you can play, and while it does work flawlessly and the game nails its table presentation, you will always play the same game, at the same location against the same adversaries, which does become boring quite easily. What will keep you playing, are the special items that each character will bring to the table as buy-in after a few rounds, giving you the opportunity to win them if you eliminate that character from the tournament; each character has one of those, making it four in total and winning those items will unlock them in Team Fortress 2, which is a nice thing if you play Team Fortress 2 as well. Even with that in mind, you can easily win those by playing a few tournaments which shouldn't take more than a few hours, and after that poker is the only thing that can bring you back, but then again, if poker is what you're here for, there are much better poker games out there. There are two difficulty levels, Normal which is the casual way to play Poker Night, allowing even the players who haven't played poker before to stand a chance by following the tutorial, and Hard which is the way to play if you really want an authentic poker experience, as the AI will become more aggressive, start bluffing and generally play smarter. The lack of additional popular poker modes such as Omaha Hold'em or Pineapple is what makes this game become boring so easily, as even with all the work put into making Texas Hold'em feel authentic, it's still the same game over and over again.
Rating: 5

Graphics
Poker Night at the Inventory isn't a visual masterpiece, but it holds on among other titles of its generation, and what really matters the most, the characters look amazing and authentic to their universe, while still fitting well in the Inventory's background. The animations are okay, but they do become repetitive as well after a while, and the visual effects, while kept to a moderate volume stand out well in the environment.
Rating: 6.5

Audio
The dialogue is what matters the most in this game, and the best part about it is that all the original voice actors for those characters are here to voice them in Poker Night, with Gary Schwartz voicing the Heavy, Matt Chapman voicing Strong Bad, William Kasten providing the voice for Max and Andrew Chaikin voicing Tycho Brahe. The soundtrack fits the mood of the Inventory perfectly and the sound effects for card flips and chips movements feel authentic, making your poker experience enjoyable, even when the dialogue starts repeating itself.
Rating: 7.5

Extras
It doesn't take more than a few hours to win all four Team Fortress 2 unlockables, which is probably where most players will end their business in Poker Night at the Inventory, but if you do decide to stay for a little longer, there are a few aesthetic unlockables such as new tables or decks, but apart from that, there is nothing else to see or do.
Rating: 6

Verdict
Poker Night at the Inventory is a fun thing to play for a few hours, which is more than enough considering its price; if you're a fan of one or multiple characters featured in this game, you'll have a great time hearing their dialogue, but if you're here for a lasting poker experience, there are probably better options out there.
Rating Overall: 6.3

reviewText:
Internet comedian Doug Walker wryly noted that people eat up crossovers like candy. It's true. Some of my favorite movies are the grand world-building events where companies worked out a way to share profits, resulting in the magic of vastly different characters coming together. Who Framed Roger Rabbit is perhaps the best example of this. More recently, there was Wreck-it Ralph, a charming CG film from Disney that showed us the secret lives of video game heroes and villains and what they do when they're off the clock. It's this simple idea that gave us Poker Night At the Inventory, and the results are pretty hysterical.

As a poker game, it's fairly straightforward stuff. Make your bet, call their bluff, walk away with the pot, and so on. The real draw of this title is the banter between your opponents. Telltale Games give us Max of Sam and Max, Strong Bad from homestarrunner.com, Heavy Weapons Guy of Team Fortress 2 fame, and Tycho, the cynical webcomic star from Penny Arcade. There's hours of dialogue crammed into the game, all of it cleverly written to develop natural relationships between these unlikely poker buddies. Most of it is truly hilarious, and you get to hear something new almost every game. As a fan of homestarrunner.com, I've always loved Strong Bad and lamented the site's long-defunct status, so merely hearing new material from the be-gloved email maestro was a real treat.

There are multiple unlocks available, notably the Team Fortress 2 items that you receive when you successfully knock out one of the other players. In addition, there are several themed decks and tables that can change the look of the game in minor and major ways. All this coupled with the fairly difficult achievement set (some of them relying on pure card-dropping luck) give Poker Night a lot of replay value.

There are some cons of course. The most glaring one is the repetition. After a few hours of play, you'll hear the same conversations over more than a couple times. You can right-click to skip previously heard dialogue, or adjust the gameplay settings to make the characters less chatty. Other reviewers have complained that the mechanics are exceptionally poor for a poker game, but I disagree. However, I suck at playing poker, so my opinion should be taken with a grain of salt. Still, I think that the players' styles fit their personalities quite well. Max is clueless, but he's dangerous as a wild card. Strong Bad isn't a good player, but he thinks he is, often bluffing his behind off and trash talking the rest of the table. Heavy is a decent cards man, but his pride can put him at a disadvantage, as he can feel that a big bet or raise is challenging his manhood. And Tycho, as a character who actually plays a lot of games himself, is the keenest of the bunch, rarely going in for high-risk pots.

Poker Night features lots of fun cameos from other Telltale and Homestar Runner characters, most of them quickly glimpsed in the opening cinematic. The music completes the setting, with a lot of remixed versions of themes from the games represented, including Sam and Max and Team Fortress 2.

Bottom line, Poker Night At the Inventory is a game made by geeks for geeks. You may enjoy it just fine as an oddball card game, but if you're familiar with the various franchises involved and get a kick out of the idea of Strong Bad getting upset over being called a tiny Heavy, then this is well worth the $4.99.

reviewText:
Short version: 81%Poker Night is a decent poker game with mediocre AI and a bunch of memorable characters whose banter will keep you entertained for a few hours. Still, if you can, skip it and play the even better sequel.

Long version:What can one say about a poker game? The computer deals you cards, and you try to win against a set of pre-determined AI players, that’s it.
As for the skill of the opponents, it’s standard. They don’t cheat, but usually play the check/fold/all in game, making it a bit hard to play against them intelligently; bullying is almost always the best tactic. They aren’t terrible, but you can always tell you are playing against bots.

So, why is this game better than any other poker game? Because of the writing: your opponents are characters from video games (and a comic strip that deals with video games), and they constantly interact with each other in well-written, humorous banter. There are hundreds, if not thousands of lines of dialogue, so it’s hard to get bored.

Still, there is one reason I wouldn’t wholeheartedly recommend this game, one large disadvantage it cannot overcome: a sequel that is superior in every aspect.

reviewText:
Poker Night at the Inventory is a well-implemented poker game, where you play no limit Texas Hold 'em.
Your opponents are Tycho (Penny Arcade), The Heavy (Team Fortress 2), Strong Bad (Homestar Runner) and Max (Sam and Max).
Poker Night's main part are the dialogues between the characters. However, you must be familiar with the characters in order to understand many of the jokes.
After a while the funny dialogue will start to lose its charm as it repeats, but you can limit it or turn it off completely after you have heard all there is to hear.
You can unlock new tables and poker decks for use and also you can unlock four aesthetic items for various TF2 classes.
The biggest issue with the game is that there is no multiplayer option. You always play with the same opponents and everyone always starts out with $10,000.

Well it is a simple game with four well known video game superstars and gives you the chance to earn TF2 items while you are playing. For that low price you can not make a mistake with a purchase.

Sound 7/10
Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 6/10
Atmosphere 7/10

reviewText:
This game, is an amazing game of Poker (Texas Hold Em' to be exact) and you get to play against Max from Sam and Max, Strong Bad from Homestar Runner, Heavy from Team Fortress 2, and Tycho from Penny Arcade. This game has you betting and checking 'till you're the last one standing. Also, at random times, one of the characters might not have the money to join the game, so they put items up for grabs, and if you win them, you get them in Team Fortress 2. To win the items, you just have to knock them out. Max is the only one in the game that puts up two items, that are his Lugermorph and his badge (A Licence to Maim in TF2), Strong Bad puts up he pair of shades ('Dangeresque, Too?' in TF2). They Heavy puts up Sasha (Iron Curtain in TF2), and Tycho bets in his watch (Enthusiast's Timepiece in TF2).
Once you've got these items, the only other real objective is to get all the achievements, which is easy considering there is only 20 (15 without the item grabs).

Overall, this game can be fun when on a plane trip, since it has character personallities, and doesn't have Multiplayer.

9/10, amazing game!

reviewText:
If you love Texas Hold 'em and these classic video game icons, you'll love Poker Night at the Inventory! In this game you get to enjoy the many different funny dialogue from the characters Max, Strong Bad, The Heavy, and Tycho. However, if you enjoy Poker as much as I do you'll find the dialogue will become stale after a while if you play for extended periods of time. Though how frequent the characters chat can be changed in the options.

If you get Poker Night solely on the purpose of playing Texas Hold 'em I would advise against it as the difficulty is novice at best. Even the harder difficulty you'll find yourself winning quite easily if you're a somewhat seasoned player of Poker.

Ultimately, if you enjoy the humor and personalities of these characters and are a novice to Poker than this game is for you. If you're somebody looking for a Poker game, then I'm afraid you've come to the wrong place. 78/100
